abstract:
<jats:p>We propose a way to formalize the relationship between descriptive analysis and structural estimation. A researcher reports an estimate 
            <jats:italic>ĉ</jats:italic> of a structural quantity of interest 
            <jats:italic>c</jats:italic> that is exactly or asymptotically unbiased under some base model. The researcher also reports descriptive statistics 
            <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline">
              <mover accent="true">
                <mi>γ</mi>
                <mo>ˆ</mo>
              </mover>
            </math> that estimate features 
            <jats:italic>γ</jats:italic> of the distribution of the data that are related to 
            <jats:italic>c</jats:italic> under the base model. A reader entertains a less restrictive model that is local to the base model, under which the estimate 
            <jats:italic>ĉ</jats:italic> may be biased. We study the reduction in worst‐case bias from a restriction that requires the reader's model to respect the relationship between 
            <jats:italic>c</jats:italic> and 
            <jats:italic>γ</jats:italic> specified by the base model. Our main result shows that the proportional reduction in worst‐case bias depends only on a quantity we call the 
            <jats:italic>informativeness</jats:italic> of 
            <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline">
              <mover accent="true">
                <mi>γ</mi>
                <mo>ˆ</mo>
              </mover>
            </math> for 
            <jats:italic>ĉ</jats:italic>. Informativeness can be easily estimated even for complex models. We recommend that researchers report estimated informativeness alongside their descriptive analyses, and we illustrate with applications to three recent papers.
          </jats:p>
title: On the Informativeness of Descriptive Statistics for Structural Estimates
subject: Economics and Econometrics
